sustain.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to make something continue to exist or happen for a period of time
sustain.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: She found it difficult to sustain the children’s interest.
He was incapable of sustaining close relationships with women.
the policies necessary to sustain economic growth
sustain.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to suffer damage, an injury, or loss of money
sustain.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Two of the firefighters sustained serious injuries.
Some nearby buildings sustained minor damage.
The company has sustained heavy financial losses this year.
sustain.translation[0].definitions[2].de: if food or drink sustains a person, animal, or plant, it makes them able to continue living
sustain.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: They gave me barely enough food to sustain me.
sustain.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to make someone feel strong and hopeful
sustain.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: The thought of seeing her again was all that sustained me.
sustain.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to hold up the weight of something
sustain.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: He leant against her so heavily that she could barely sustain his weight.
sustain.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to support an idea or argument, or prove that it is right
sustain.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: This argument is difficult to sustain.
sustain.translation[1].definitions[0].de: if a company sustains losses or other difficulties, it has them
sustain.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Like other insurance companies, we havesustained heavylosses.
The record industrysustained a salesslump in the first half.
sustain.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to manage to make something continue to exist over a long period of time
sustain.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The Dow Jones broke above the 2935 level in the early afternoon but was unable to sustain the gains.
Officials predict the electronics industry will be able tosustain growth.
